awd_titl_txt: Undoped NaI/CsI Directly Coupled to PMTs at 77 K for Rare-Event Searches
awd_abstract_narration:
Dark matter and neutrino properties are among the most compelling problems to be studied in modern physics. Dark matter particles may be detected through the observation of nuclear recoils produced when they scatter with nuclei in a target. Nuclear recoils can also be created when neutrinos coherently scatter with nuclei. This process, if ever observed, would help in probing non-standard neutrino interactions, searching for sterile neutrinos, and understanding the explosion mechanism of core-collapse supernovae. Both scattering rates increase dramatically as the energies of nuclear recoils go down. The lower the energy threshold of a detector, the more events can be detected. 

Recent activity in the SURF underground laboratory stimulated support from the South Dakota state to the expansion of PhD programs at state universities. The activity planned with this award provides an opportunity for a PhD student to take part in research related to underground science. The activity may also pave the way for practical applications of undoped NaI/CsI at 77 K in civil uses. For example, un-doped NaI at 77 K has a much faster scintillation signal than NaI/CsI(Tl) at room temperature. It can be used to improve the time and position resolution of PET, resulting in more precise imaging of the concerned tissue of a patient.

A straight forward way to lower the energy threshold of a scintillation detector is to increase its light yield. This award is focused on optimizing the light readout from un-doped NaI/CsI at 77 K. Both sodium iodide and cesium iodide doped with thallium, NaI/CsI(Tl), are excellent scintillators at room temperature. The PI plans to couple un-doped NaI/CsI directly to the photomultiplier tubes (PMTs), cool them down to 77 K to maximize the light readout. Low temperature properties of the PMTs will be compared; dimensions and various surface treatments of un-doped NaI/CsI crystals will be examined to optimize the light collection efficiency. The goal is to verify whether it is possible to lower the energy threshold by a factor of two by increasing the light yield by a factor of two, compared to existing experiments utilizing NaI/CsI(Tl) at room temperature. The decay times of scintillation light from un-doped NaI/CsI at 77 K are quite different from those of NaI/CsI(Tl) at room temperature. Their effect on signal and background discrimination will also be examined.

por.por_cntn:
The feasibility of using undoped inorganic scintillating crystals directly coupled to photomultiplier tubes at -321 Fahrenheit for the detection of dark matter and neutrino particles has been investigated in various aspects.

Given the same amount of energy deposited by particles in the crystal, the amount of scintillation light emitted by the crystal that can be  detected in such a system has been experimentally proven to be at least twice higher than the highest achieved in traditional setups, where  impurity-doped crystals are coupled with photomultiplier tubes at room temperature. The more light can be detected, the more low energy particles can be detected. Both dark matter and neutrino interactions beyond the Standard Model of particle physics populate at very low energy regions. This new combination operated at an unconventional temperature region hence opens the possibility of detecting more signals  given the same detector mass.

The low temperature operation of scintillating crystals is more cumbersome than those at room temperature. A series of scientific papers has been published over the life time of this project to describe the experimental setups and methods that made such an operation not only possible but also fruitful.

Based on these experimental investigations, the performance of a 10 kg prototype detector for the detection of low-mass dark matter and non- standard neutrino interactions at the Spallation Neutron Source, Oak Ridge National Laboratory has been studied in detail though Monte Carlo simulations and theoretical calculations. Its sensitivities for these detections have been proven to be much better than detectors in the same mass scale.

This project has provided a great opportunity for next-generation instrumentalists to obtain a comprehensive training in every aspect of     radiation detector development, from the design of detectors, to the analysis of experimental data and the study of physics potential of the novel detector system. Up to now, two postdoctoral researchers have worked on this project. Both of them continued their research in other universities. Three students graduates with a M.S. degree. Three undergraduate students graduated with this study as the topic of their Honors Thesis. More than five undergraduate students did undergraduate research or summer internship working on this project. One of them was selected to present his research to congress members in the annual "Posters on the (Capitol) Hill" event, and received the Undergraduate Research Excellence award at the University of South Dakota.

A series of curriculum development has been done utilizing topics and techniques involved in this project for the education of students at   the University of South Dakota through three new topical courses. The course material has been further developed for a summer school, where  more than 50 students from all over the world benefited from it. Furthermore, a series of YouTube videos was developed introducing Monte Carlo simulation techniques developed for this project. More than 6000 views and 100 subscribers have been achieved up to now.

To summarize, the project not only demonstrated a new direction in dark matter and neutrino detection but also provided a platform for the training of a broad range of students and researchers.
